Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Persistent low mood, loss of interest in daily activities for the past 6 months

Present Illness.Onset: Onset 6 months ago, at home, gradual onset with periods of mild improvement and worsening, prodromal symptoms included occasional sadness, potential trigger might be the loss of a close friend
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Patient reports persistent low mood, describes it as a heaviness in his chest, constant throughout the day, severity moderate to severe, temporary improvement when with family, worse in the mornings, progression slow but steady decline
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Low self-esteem, self-blame, occasional suicidal thoughts (denies plans or intent), poor concentration, difficulty sleeping (insomnia), decreased appetite
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Visited family physician 4 months ago, prescribed antidepressants which provided minimal relief, attended 3 sessions of cognitive-behavioral therapy with limited success
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state: depressed mood, Sleep: disrupted with frequent awakenings, Appetite: reduced, Urination and Defecation: normal, Weight: minor unintentional weight loss (~5 lbs)

Past History.General Health Condition: Previously in good health with mild age-related changes
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: Left hip replacement 5 years ago, no complications

Personal History.Living Habits: Lives alone, previously active in community, reduced social interaction in recent months, non-smoker, occasional alcohol use
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Retired engineer, previously worked in office settings
Personal History.Exposure History: No known exposure to industrial toxins, dust, radioactive substances
Personal History.Travel History: Limited travel in recent years due to age and mobility issues

Marital History.Marriage Age: Married at 25, spouse passed 10 years ago
Marital History.Children's Condition: Two adult children, both in good health, maintain regular contact

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father had depression, mother deceased due to stroke, two siblings (one with hypertension, other in good health)

Systematic Examination.Skin: Normal for age, no lesions or rashes
Systematic Examination.Chest: Normal shape, clear to auscultation bilaterally, heart sounds regular without murmurs
Systematic Examination.Spine: Normal alignment, mild tenderness in lumbar region
Systematic Examination.Limbs: No edema, full range of motion in all joints
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert and oriented, cranial nerves II-XII intact, motor strength 5/5 in all extremities, sensory normal, reflexes 2+ and equal

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Psychiatric examination: Patient appears anxious and depressed, eye contact poor, speech slow, thought process logical but with themes of hopelessness and worthlessness
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: CBC, CMP, TSH, Vitamin B12, and folate levels within normal limits; Head CT showed age-appropriate brain atrophy, no acute changes
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: History of persistent low mood, loss of interest, and accompanying symptoms; physical and psychiatric examination; exclusion of other medical causes through lab tests
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Depression related to physical illness (excluded by normal test results), dementia (no significant cognitive impairment detected), schizophrenia (no psychotic symptoms), post-traumatic stress disorder (no trauma history), bipolar depression (no manic episodes)

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted for further evaluation and management of depression. Plan includes continued antidepressant therapy, adjusting dosage, initiating psychotherapy, and monitoring for suicidal ideation.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Patient reports slight improvement in mood with medication adjustment. Continues to have difficulty sleeping. Will initiate sleep hygiene education and consider sleep aid if necessary.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Senior physician agrees with current management plan, suggests increasing psychotherapy frequency.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: No significant overnight changes, patient stable, plan to continue current treatment strategy.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Following 1 week of treatment, patient reports moderate improvement in mood, better sleep, appetite remains low. Will continue current therapeutic regimen.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Consultation with psychiatry confirmed diagnosis and recommended combined pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Sertraline 50mg daily, Trazodone 50mg at bedtime if needed for sleep, General diet, Fall precautions, Daily psychiatrist visits
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: CBC and CMP in 1 week, Increase Sertraline to 75mg if no significant effect in 2 weeks
